Award.AwardTitle: BRAIN EAGER:The Virtual Neuroanatomist: Using Machine Intelligence to Study Intelligent Machines
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cutting-edge light microscopy technology allows entire vertebrate brains to be digitized, resulting in data sets of unprecedented size and complexity. However there is a lack of adequate computational tools to visualize, manage, analyze, and disseminate these enormous data sets, and visual examination by expert human neuroanatomists remains the standard method to extract information from microscopic images. Software tools exist that can perform simple operations, but they are not able to adequately mimic the visual pattern recognition skills of an experienced neuroanatomist. This project aims to develop computational tools that mimic the analysis of an expert neuroanatomist, thus allowing for rich data analysis of whole-brain light microscopy data sets on a scale that has been previously intractable using human experts.

Machine vision algorithms will be developed and integrated into an an open source software toolbox (with associated whole brain image data) that will be made widely accessible for further development and refinement. Pattern recognition methodology will be applied to combine information about brain location (e.g., "where are we in the brain") with information about correspondence of brain structures in different species (e.g., "which areas of the brain of these species correspond"). Incorporating comparative neuroanatomical knowledge into pattern-recognition methodology is radically different from the "atlas morphing" approach currently used, and has the potential to transform the study of whole-brain neuroanatomy. The tools will help fill a gap in knowledge and skills (as contemporary neuroanatomists are increasingly less frequently being trained to study whole-brain microscopic anatomy), and postdoc and PhD students will be trained in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The present work was motivated by a technical challenge: in the face of growing volumes of high-resolution brain image data gathered using light microscopy, we need to virtualize the expertise of experienced neuroanatomists so that this data can be effectively analyzed, i.e. develop a “virtual neuroanatomist”. Such virtualization of expertise is particularly timely in the current era of artificial intelligence, and is essential for both scientific and medical brain research. Previously, computational neuroanatomy work has largely focused on data sets acquired using magnetic resonance imaging. Such data sets are at millimeter resolution, and contain millions of voxels or data elements. In comparison, the light microscopy generated brain images are at micron resolution, and contain trillions of voxels. This large scale-up poses nontrivial algorithmic and computational challenges, which were addressed as part of the proposed work.

 

The outcome of this proposal is a set of algorithms and software that can address this challenge, and its application to a large petabyte-sized neuroanatomical data set. A primary challenge addressed was the “where” problem: which brain region does a specific point in a neuroanatomical image correspond to? Traditionally, neuroanatomists have made this determination using a manual “mapping” procedure, to visually judge location in a reference atlas by examining printed histological atlases. A major focus of the activity was therefore the automation of such location judgment, and a suite of algorithms and software tools were implemented for this purpose. Another important challenge is to analyze the content of the images. Neuroanatomists, when examining neurohistological images, can identify fragments of neurons visible in a particular image, corresponding to a neuronal cell body or soma, dendrites and axons. Thus, algorithms were developed to automatically segment and classify objects in the images, corresponding to these neuronal compartments. Finally, algorithms and software were assembled together to implement a workflow that permitted the full chain of analysis, to produce scientifically actionable output.

 

The output of this project is expected to be useful for the scientific analysis of brain image data. Interestingly, the same tools may also find application to histopathological image data used in the diagnoses of tissue biopsies. This project also had a significant impact in drawing in computational researchers who have previously not been engaged in the analysis of light-microscopic neuroanatomical data. Such computational researchers became engaged across multiple institutions, working collaboratively, and as a result, students and postdocs also received training in this new field.
